title: What Is Pulse Oximetry?
author: Stephanie Watson, Kathryn Whitbourne

sections.heading: What Is a Pulse Oximeter?
content: A pulse oximeter, or pulse ox, is an electronic device that can be attached to your forehead, fingers, nose, foot, toes, or ears. A nurse or medical assistant usually clamps this around your fingertip for a few seconds when you go for a routine medical checkup.
A pulse oximeter measures how much oxygen is in your blood. The device gives you two readings. (Photo Credit: Moment/Getty Images)
Pulse oximetry is the name of the test using the pulse ox. It's a quick, inexpensive, and needle-free way to measure the amount of oxygen in your blood .
What does a pulse oximeter measure?
It measures whether your heart and lungs supply enough oxygen to the rest of your body to meet its needs.

Red blood cells carry oxygen from your lungs to your organs. But lung or heart disease can lower the amount of oxygen in these cells. When it drops too low, your body doesn’t work as well as it should. Your heart, brain , and other organs need oxygen to do their job.
Your doctor can use this test to find out if you need to breathe in extra oxygen through a tube (your doctor may call it supplemental oxygen) or to be treated for a heart or lung problem.

sections.heading: How Does a Pulse Oximeter Work?
content: The pulse oximeter measures how much light is absorbed in your blood. It has two light emitters and one light detector (sensor). The device shines two wavelengths of light through the tissue on your fingertip (or wherever the device was placed) and into the sensor. One wavelength is red and the other is infrared.
The sensor can tell you how much of each wavelength was absorbed, thus letting you know what percentage of oxygen is in your red blood cells. This is the oxygen saturation level.
What are the two readings on a pulse oximeter?
When you look at the digital display on  a pulse ox, you should see two readings.
bullets: Blood that has a lot of oxygen absorbs more infrared light.
Blood that doesn't have enough oxygen absorbs more red light.

SpO2 (blood oxygen saturation level). This should be 95%-100% if everything is normal. If it's lower than 95%, you should be monitored by a doctor. If your measurement is 90%-92% or less, you may need supplemental oxygen.
PR (pulse rate). This tells how fast your heart is beating. Normal is 60-100 beats per minute. If it's 101-130, see your doctor for monitoring. If it's 131 or higher, go to the emergency room.

sections.heading: Reasons for Pulse Oximetry
content: Your doctor will use pulse oximetry whenever they think that your blood oxygen levels could be too low. The device can help:
The device is also often part of a routine medical checkup.
You might need pulse oximetry if you have:
Pulse oximeter for infants

In the U.S., all newborns are given a pulse ox by law. This is to screen for heart defects. About 1% of all babies are born with heart defects, meaning their heart didn't form properly. Of the babies born with heart defects, 25% have critical congenital heart disease, which leads to low levels of oxygen. Babies with this condition usually need surgery in their first year of life to correct their heart problem.

To perform a pulse ox on a baby, the health care provider wraps a soft sensor around the infant's right hand and one foot. The sensor is attached to a monitor for 5 minutes before the provider reads it. The test is usually done 24 hours after birth. A normal newborn heart rate is 70 to 190 beats per minute. If the readings are not normal, the baby will need more tests like blood tests and an echocardiogram.

Track your blood oxygen level during surgery
Determine if lung medicines are working
Test oxygen levels when you use supplemental oxygen
Show if you need extra oxygen when you exercise

sections.heading: What Happens During the Test?
content: You may get pulse oximetry during a doctor's visit or hospital stay.
Your nurse will clip the pulse ox on your finger, toe, or ear . Or they’ll put a sticky disposable probe on your finger, nose, toe, or forehead.
The pulse oximeter uses a special type of light to see how much oxygen is in the red blood cells traveling through the blood vessels under your skin .
The test is painless and quick. In just a few seconds, the device will show your heart rate and oxygen saturation level — the percentage of your red blood cells carrying oxygen.
Your nurse will take the clip off if it’s just a one-time check. During surgery or a sleep study, it may stay in place to track your blood oxygen.

You should be able to go home after pulse oximetry unless you need to stay in the hospital for a procedure or more monitoring. Your doctor will let you know what happens next and what to do after the test.

sections.heading: At-Home Pulse Oximetry
content: Home monitoring became popular during the COVID-19 pandemic. (COVID-19 can weaken your lungs and lower your blood oxygen levels.) . There are two main types of home pulse oximeters: over-the-counter and prescription.
Over-the-counter oximeters
This is the more common type for home use. You can buy them online or in stores without a prescription. They are inexpensive.

The FDA normally recommends against using them for medical purposes because it hasn't reviewed them for accuracy. However, the first FDA-approved OTC pulse ox (the Masimo MightySat Medical) came out in 2024.
Prescription oximeters

These are the same as those used by hospitals and doctor's offices. You can get one with a prescription from your doctor. The FDA reviews these devices to make sure they fall within acceptable ranges of accuracy.
Prescription oximeters are more expensive than OTC oximeters. Some insurance companies will pay for a pulse oximeter. Check with your provider.
How to take a pulse ox reading
Follow guidance from your doctor and the device manufacturer on how and when to take a reading. You can help improve your chances of accurate and useful readings if you:
bullets: Sit comfortably for a few minutes before taking a reading.
Make sure your hand is relaxed, warm, and below heart level.
Remove any fingernail polish on the finger you’re reading.
Place the device exactly how the manufacturer's instructions suggest.
Look for one steady number. (Numbers might jump around for a few seconds.)
Keep track of your levels along with the date and time to give your doctor a sense for how your numbers change over time. (Levels that get lower over time could suggest a serious health issue).

sections.heading: Pulse oximeter apps
content: A variety of pulse oximeter apps are out there. Some sync up with your smartwatch or Fitbit. Others simply use the flash feature and camera in your smartphone. The flash comes on via the app, you place a finger on your camera lens, and wait a minute or so for results. The apps are not FDA approved, and most state they aren't to be marketed for medical diagnosis. They may give a false reading in either direction.

sections.heading: Pulse Oximeter Readings
content: A pulse oximeter reading is just one of many signs of your health. Pay attention to all of your symptoms and tell your doctor about anything that concerns you, especially if you have an underlying health condition like lung disease.
It’s also important to know that some people with low oxygen might not show any symptoms. Only your doctor can determine whether you have low oxygen levels (which they might call hypoxia).
Pulse oximeter normal range

content_blocks.text: A pulse oximeter reading is just one of many signs of your health. Pay attention to all of your symptoms and tell your doctor about anything that concerns you, especially if you have an underlying health condition like lung disease.
It’s also important to know that some people with low oxygen might not show any symptoms. Only your doctor can determine whether you have low oxygen levels (which they might call hypoxia).
Pulse oximeter normal range

content: A normal blood oxygen level is 95%-100%. A blood oxygen level lower than 89% means you may not have enough oxygen in your blood to meet your body's needs. This could be because there’s a problem with your heart or lungs. If your levels are low, you may need to breathe in extra oxygen through a tube. Levels that are a little higher (in the low 90s) might still be abnormal if no other medical history to explain it.

A pulse oximeter reading is simply an estimate . Pulse oximeters have an accuracy deviation of 2%-4%. That means for example, a reading of 90% oxygen saturation on an FDA-approved prescription machine could really be anything from 86% to 94%. In addition, a number of other things can affect the accuracy of the reading, including:
bullets: Bad circulation
Fingernail polish
Long or dirty fingernails
Tobacco use
Different pulse oximeter sensors (finger clip vs. adhesive)
Skin thickness
Skin temperature
Inaccurate placement of the device

Skin color: Studies have suggested that people with dark skin may get less accurate measurements on current devices. That's because melanin absorbs light and the more melanin you have, the more light you may absorb, thus altering the readings.

content: Other symptoms of low oxygen include:
Call your doctor right away if you notice any of these symptoms, no matter what readings you get on your home device.
bullets: Difficulty catching your breath
Bluish color in nails, face, or lips
Racing pulse
Tightness or pain in chest
A cough that gets worse over time
General feeling of discomfort and restlessness

Skin color: Studies have suggested that people with dark skin may get less accurate measurements on current devices. That's because melanin absorbs light and the more melanin you have, the more light you may absorb, thus altering the readings.

content_blocks.text: A normal blood oxygen level is 95%-100%. A blood oxygen level lower than 89% means you may not have enough oxygen in your blood to meet your body's needs. This could be because there’s a problem with your heart or lungs. If your levels are low, you may need to breathe in extra oxygen through a tube. Levels that are a little higher (in the low 90s) might still be abnormal if no other medical history to explain it.

A pulse oximeter reading is simply an estimate . Pulse oximeters have an accuracy deviation of 2%-4%. That means for example, a reading of 90% oxygen saturation on an FDA-approved prescription machine could really be anything from 86% to 94%. In addition, a number of other things can affect the accuracy of the reading, including:

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: A pulse oximeter (pulse ox) is a device normally clipped to your forefinger when you go to your doctor for a routine wellness check or when you're in hospital with a condition like COPD, lung cancer, heart disease, or COVID-19. It measures how much oxygen is in your blood. This is known as your oxygen saturation level. A normal reading would be 95%-100% oxygen saturation level. If the level is below 90%, you may need supplemental oxygen. A pulse ox reading shouldn't be the only method of diagnosing a medical problem. Usually the doctor will run other tests. If you have an at-home device, be sure to get any abnormal readings double-checked with a doctor. Also, pay attention to other signs that might signal low oxygen like shortness of breath.

sections.heading: Pulse Oximetry FAQs
content: What is the principle of oximetry? Pulse oximetry is based on the principle that oxygenated blood and deoxygenated blood (blood with a reduced concentration of oxygen) absorb red and infrared light differently. Oxygen-rich blood absorbs more infrared light, while oxygen-poor blood absorbs more red light. By measuring how much of each type of light the pulse oximeter absorbs, you can know how much oxygen is in the blood.

content: Which finger should you use for a pulse oximeter?

Usually it's the index or middle finger. One small study found that the middle finger on the right hand (the dominant hand) gave the most accurate results, followed by the right thumb and the index finger, but the SpO2 differences between the three were not that significant. One survey showed 80% of health care providers use the index finger to take readings.
What is overnight pulse oximetry?

This is a test to check your breathing while you sleep. It's used to check for sleep apnea and other disorders. You'll wear a clip with a sensor on your index or middle finger connected to a wrist monitor. This sensor shines a light through your finger and measures the oxygen in your blood.
